titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the William Bryans Papers MC.29
titlestmt.author: Megan Findling.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2023-08-12 07:03:22 -0400.

change.item: Updated by Jacqueline Rider for compliance with DACS and ACM Required Elements for Archival Description

did.abstract: This collection documents the history of the College of Engineering as written by a New York University (NYU) faculty member. Bryans served both as Assistant Dean and Professor of Engineering Mechanics at the College of Engineering in his four-decade career at the University. The collection contains manuscripts of and photographs from two separate histories of the College written by Bryans.
did.physloc: Materials are stored offsite and advance notice is required for use. Please request materials at least two business days prior to your research visit to coordinate access.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date (if known); The William Bryans Papers; MC 29; box number; folder number; New York University Archives

p.extref: Records of the Student Army Training Corps 1916 - 1921

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: This collection is protected by copyright and/or related rights. You are free to use materials in the collection in any way that is permitted by the copyright and related rights legislation that applies to your use. For other uses you need to obtain permission from the rights-holder(s).

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The materials in this collection are arranged by manuscript and further by format.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This collection documents the historical research of an NYU alumnus who went on to serve the University as both a professor and an administrator. The collection contains manuscripts for two works on the history of the College of Engineering as well as photographs that illustrate each manuscript.

bioghist.head: Biography of William Bryans
bioghist.p: Born in New York City, William R. Bryans (1884-1974) attended Manual Training High School in Brooklyn from 1895-1902 before attending New York University (NYU). He graduated NYU with a B.S. in Mechanical Engineering in 1906 and achieved the degree of Mechanical Engineer in 1909. Less than a year after graduation, Bryans took his first job at NYU, where he continued to work for over four decades in many capacities, including as a Professor of Engineering Mechanics, the Secretary of Faculty, and Assistant Dean. In 1949 he was named Professor Emeritus and was granted an Honorary Doctorate in Engineering.

During his academic career Bryans published several papers on the mechanics of materials and engineering education. He also authored two books, Concise Mechanics of Materials and Mechanics of Internal Work in 1928 and Resistance of Materials in 1931.

Bryans was a member of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers, the Society for the Promotion of Engineering Education, the American Association for the Advancement of Science, the American Association of University Professors, Iota Alpha, and the NYU Faculty Club. During World War I, Bryans served as Assistant Director in charge of instruction for the Student Army Training Corps from 1917-1918.
